title: TypeCon Auction: Yes or No?
content:
I will attend TypeCon and will participate in the auction, including donating an item.

24% (14 votes)

I will attend TypeCon and will participate in the auction, but will not donate any items.

14% (8 votes)

I won't be able to attend this year, but will donate something for the auction.

3% (2 votes)

 I won't be able to attend TypeCon this year and do not have anything to donate for the auction.

44% (26 votes)

I will be attending TypeCon but could not give a crap about the auction.

15% (9 votes)

Total votes: 59
author: Miss Tiffany

As someone who enjoys a good auction, thinks Dave does a great job at actioneering, and who has spent some serious money at both ATypI and TypeCon auctions, I voted that I don’t give a crap about the auction. I guess I’ve lost interest.

In San Francisco, I found a copy of Big Red in one of the antique stores. I told Dave about it and we went over and he bought it for $175. A great price for Big Red. Anyway, he put that up for auction asking an opening bid of $175. NO ONE bid on it! He took it off the table, and not wanting to bring it back to England (he already had a copy) offered to sell it to me. I accepted.

In order to have a good auction, you need people willing to spend some money. That is not been my experience with the TypeCon auctions.
That is a lot for Big Red. I found my copy for $40. Yes. I wonder if we aren’t at the point where people have what they want and don’t want to part with what they have.

I have to admit I rarely find stuff I really want at the TypeCon/ATypI auctions, so I don’t usually get into a bidding frenzy.

T

$40 for 1912 ATF Big Red is a unheard of bargain. Good for you! Most of what I have seen is in the $190 -$250 range.

I have to agree with Thomas on the articles for auction at TypeCon.

I should add that I \*used\* to find more stuff I wanted, but then I acquired the stuff I really wanted, and now I’m mostly done. I guess I’m just not a good enough consumer. :/

Though I’m still interested in ATF specimen books \*prior\* to the 1912 one, come to think of it. (Not counting the 1905 ornaments and borders book.)

T

I have never been one to collect antiques so I guess I am not the kind of person who is looking for things of historic value or collectables. I am more interested in very well done typography even if it is recent. I am also interested in information, technical, historical, or scientific, which relates to typography, type design, readability, linguistics and the history of letterforms and scripts. I would be interested in a copy of Miles Tinker’s “Legibility of Print” since I can’t seem to find it.  
Since I have never witnessed an auction of any kind. I really don’t know what to expect. I might be just as happy with a yard sale style of thing.

ChrisL
I am pretty sure I don’t have anything fab to offer. What kinds of things have gone under the hammer in the past?

\>What kinds of things have gone under the hammer in the past?

Typing ‘typecon auction’ into the search engines results in quite a good overview of what’s up for grabs, basically old type specimens, ephemera, font packs, design magazines, posters, t-shirts, signed-books, old books, film strips, discs, wood type, John Downer hand painted banners, old signs, David Lemon’s Pokemon keyring, etc., you known the normal stuff that occupies the shoeboxes and bookcases of the typorati.
Simon I think you need to officially add that word — [Typorati](http://web.archive.org/wiki/Typorati) — to the wiki. ;^)
Good idea - I think that Veer were the first to use it. Time for some research.

In SF I got a profusely autographed copy of John Berry’s “Contemporary Newspaper Design” for pretty much retail price. And I donated something: tragicomically pretentious letterpress “Don’t Mention It” cards\* that I’d printed like two days before the conference. I’m not a big auction buyer by any means, but at ATypI I’ve bought: old issues of TypeLab; Fiona Ross’s book; and a tight little Soviet lettering booklet. Oh, and I donated a German-Tibetan dictionary at ATypI-Leipzig (and I’m still dying to find out who ended up with it). So clearly I think these auctions are worthwhile. Just not worth 5 hours.

\* You send them in the true bourgeois spirit of oneupmanship in response to a “Thank You” card. :-)

BTW, I totally agree with David Berlow that TypeCon must  
not loose sight of its sort of “blue collar”, populist essence.  
The Nikko was a mistake.
